content: Career Asked by AnonymousAsked on 20 Aug 2019How have you dealt with questions by current existing colleagues when going for job interviews?Do you tell them frankly that you are interviewing for another potential job? Or do you try to come up with another reason?3 answersAnswerBump0

Jacqueline YanLevel 4. ProdigyUpdated on 25 Aug 2019I suppose this depends on the culture at your workplace, is it more sensitive towards such topics? Also how close you are with these colleagues?
I recently gone through something similar and to most of the colleagues, I told them that I had my own appointments. But to the closer ones, I did share that I was going for a job interview.2 comments2

WMWeber Mak20 Aug 2019Smile and leave it unanswered until you signed and confirmed the jobJacqueline Yan25 Aug 2019Luckily my colleagues didn't really ask me much. But yea, I only told the rest when I got my confirmation.

Junus EuTop Contributor (Sep)Level 8. WizardAnswered on 22 Aug 2019Only for really close work buddies whom you trust. The only time I did personally was when the whole team was interviewing for other jobs, because of the toxic culture in the company.Otherwise, I have seen cases where some nosey gossip mongers spread the word, and if it reaches HR, HR tells your manager, Manager comes to you to ask you what's going on (especially if it's a difficult manager), then GG.0 comments1

Yong Kah HweeLevel 6. MasterAnswered on 21 Aug 2019I think it depends on what kind of colleagues you have. If you don't feel like it's 'safe' telling your colleagues, then don't. But if your colleagues are trustworthy and won't backstab you by telling your bosses that you are leaving soon, then sure, just tell :)0 comments0
